author: 4d8c
content: General question about gas fees. Shouldnt gas fees always rise to the point of profitability of using the network? And that's for any network.

author: sky.cactus
content: <#692078615269212180> for further discussion, but yes more or less.  It reduces to a simple supply/demand problem where each block has a fixed supply of block space, and there is some public demand for blockspace at that time.  The price will rise, reducing demand, until the two are equal.

author: 4d8c
content: But if there is X profit to be obtained then shouldn't the transaction cost rise to meet that? So the more profitable it is to be making transactions the higher fees will rise?

author: sky.cactus
content: The "profitability" of using Ethereum just increases demand, but otherwise doesn't change the calculus.

author: 4d8c
content: So we should expect cost of using the network to rise to meet it's most profitable users?

author: sky.cactus
content: I wouldn't say "most profitable users" as much as "the users willing to pay the most".

author: 4d8c
content: Mmm good point. I'm making the assumption that those willing to pay the most intend to eventually accrue more than that expense

author: 4d8c
content: I guess my concern is around gas fees always rising as those using the network become more profitable, regardless of mitigations against that, effectively leading to an inevitable pricing out of most users, and if this has been considered.
